title: Contributing new tests
text: Testing performed via testthat framework. tests given function placed dedicated test-function.R file. test comprised one expectations descriptive name. E.g. multiple tests made single object, often useful create object outside test_that function. particularly useful different descriptive texts shown tests (e.g. perhaps coefficients standard errors model): objects useful test, can created within test_that function. Making description test meaningful important, help user diagnose problem . testthat supports large number expectations, documented testthat documentation. demonstrate examples .
code: test_that("some meaningful message about the tests", {   expect_equal(1 + 1, 2)   expect_true(is.numeric(1))   expect_false(is.character(1)) }) obj <- some_function(params) test_that("test 1 on obj", {   expect_equal(obj$value_to_test, expected_value) }) test_that("test 2 on obj", {   expect_equal(obj$another_value_to_test, expected_value) }) test_that("tests on obj", {   obj <- some_function(params)   expect_equal(obj$value_to_test, expected_value)   expect_equal(obj$another_value_to_test, expected_value) })

Use regexp argument check particular error, warning message. contrast, test whether function runs without returning error, warning message, following corresponding code can adapted, many test cases considered appropriate:
code: test_that("function f returns an error", {   expect_error(f(x)) })  test_that("function f returns a warning", {   expect_warning(f(x)) })  test_that("function f returns a message", {   expect_message(f(x)) }) test_that("function f returns an error", {   expect_error(f(x), regexp = "some error message") }) test_that("function f runs without error", {   expect_no_error(f(x)) })  test_that("function f runs without a warning", {   expect_warning(f(x)) })  test_that("function f runs without a message", {   expect_message(f(x)) })

text: First write actual tests want run. Tests entered test-lm.R file. Opening file, see just comments top file, reminders. decide use mtcars dataset basis testing lm, can load dataset. want test linear effect number cylinders miles per gallon, effect number cylinders (cyl), well cyl treated factor. code: # Write relevent tests for the function in here # Consider the type of function: #   - is it deterministic or statistic? #   - is it worth checking for errors/warnings under particular conditions? # Write relevent tests for the function in here # Consider the type of function: #   - is it deterministic or statistic? #   - is it worth checking for errors/warnings under particular conditions?  data(mtcars) mtcars$cyl_f <- factor(mtcars$cyl) cmod <- lm(mpg ~ cyl, data = mtcars) fmod <- lm(mpg ~ cyl_f, data = mtcars)

title: Contributing new tests
text: Suppose know coefficient mpg ~ cyl known (-2.88 linear effect). can write test checks expectation: Due floating point precision, probably insufficient - R return exactly -2.88. can use tolerance argument check coefficient within certain range (also round coefficient). also need tell expect_equal ignore names attribute vector, otherwise compares whole object, attributes : can coefficients model cyl_f. time, can derive values tapply function , case, coefficients just means: now performed 4 tests (expectations) two test_that calls. can also combine together: Whether put one two calls author. Distributing across calls helps identify tests fail, also makes file longer.
code: test_that("lm returns the expected coefficients", {   expect_equal(coef(cmod)[2], -2.88) }) test_that("lm returns the expected coefficients", {   expect_equal(coef(cmod)[2], -2.88, tolerance = 0.01, check.attributes = FALSE) }) test_that("lm returns the expected coefficients", {   means <- tapply(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl, mean)   coefs <- coef(fmod)   expect_equal(coefs[1], means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[2], means[2] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[3], means[3] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE) }) test_that("lm returns the expected coefficients", {   expect_equal(coef(cmod)[2], -2.88, tolerance = 0.01, check.attributes = FALSE)      means <- tapply(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl, mean)   coefs <- coef(fmod)   expect_equal(coefs[1], means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[2], means[2] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[3], means[3] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE) })

title: Contributing new tests
text: tolerance tricky thing select. balance strict lenient. tolerance strict, test fail function working expected. tolerance lenient, test pass function working expected. Consider example . compared -2.88 coefficient R reports (least) 5 decimal places. case, make sense use tolerance less 0.01 know coefficient two decimal places (even though access far greater precision worked ). Generally speaking, values easy calculate probably lower tolerance. Values dependent specifics implementation (e.g. maximisation algorithm, etc) probably higher tolerance. especially case using external software reference (e.g. Stata uses different defaults settings lme4, causing differences SEs). Simulation results, may also require lenient tolerance.

what: Testing the standard errors against Stata
title: Contributing new tests
text: Suppose used Stata reference software standard errors. include commands used reference software comments script, including output information version reference software. can use SE values Stata tests, specifying suitable tolerance (’s pretty simple calculate, can quite stringent):
code: # write.csv(mtcars, "mtcars.csv", row.names = FALSE) # reference software: Stata 17.0 (revision 2024-02-13) # import delimited "mtcars.csv" # regress mpg cyl # [output truncated for brevity] # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ #          mpg | Coefficient  Std. err.      t    P>|t|     [95% conf. interval] # -------------+---------------------------------------------------------------- #          cyl |   -2.87579   .3224089    -8.92   0.000    -3.534237   -2.217343 #        _cons |   37.88458   2.073844    18.27   0.000     33.64922    42.11993 # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # [output truncated for brevity] # regress mpg i.cyl # [output truncated for brevity] test_that("Standard errors from LM are correct", {   expect_equal(summary(cmod)$coefficients[2, 2], 0.322408,                 tolerance = 0.00001)   expect_equal(summary(fmod)$coefficients[2, 2], 1.558348,                 tolerance = 0.00001)   expect_equal(summary(fmod)$coefficients[3, 2], 1.298623,                 tolerance = 0.0001) })

title: Contributing new tests
text: test file including tests : lm, things might tested include R-squared, F-statistic, p-values. Generally speaking, might also want test model appropriate class (also lm case), model expected number coefficients, function issues warnings /errors appropriate times.
code: # Write relevent tests for the function in here # Consider the type of function: #   - is it deterministic or statistic? #   - is it worth checking for errors/warnings under particular conditions?  data(mtcars) mtcars$cyl_f <- factor(mtcars$cyl)  cmod <- lm(mpg ~ cyl, data = mtcars) fmod <- lm(mpg ~ cyl_f, data = mtcars)  test_that("lm returns the expected coefficients", {   expect_equal(coef(cmod)[2], -2.88, tolerance = 0.01, check.attributes = FALSE)      means <- tapply(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$cyl, mean)   coefs <- coef(fmod)   expect_equal(coefs[1], means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[2], means[2] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE)   expect_equal(coefs[3], means[3] - means[1], check.attributes = FALSE) })  # write.csv(mtcars, "mtcars.csv", row.names = FALSE) # reference software: Stata 17.0 (revision 2024-02-13) # import delimited "mtcars.csv" # regress mpg cyl #  #       Source |       SS           df       MS      Number of obs   =        32 # -------------+----------------------------------   F(1, 30)        =     79.56 #        Model |  817.712952         1  817.712952   Prob > F        =    0.0000 #     Residual |  308.334235        30  10.2778078   R-squared       =    0.7262 # -------------+----------------------------------   Adj R-squared   =    0.7171 #        Total |  1126.04719        31  36.3241028   Root MSE        =    3.2059 #  # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ #          mpg | Coefficient  Std. err.      t    P>|t|     [95% conf. interval] # -------------+---------------------------------------------------------------- #          cyl |   -2.87579   .3224089    -8.92   0.000    -3.534237   -2.217343 #        _cons |   37.88458   2.073844    18.27   0.000     33.64922    42.11993 # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ # regress mpg i.cyl #  #       Source |       SS           df       MS      Number of obs   =        32 # -------------+----------------------------------   F(2, 29)        =     39.70 #        Model |   824.78459         2  412.392295   Prob > F        =    0.0000 #     Residual |  301.262597        29  10.3883654   R-squared       =    0.7325 # -------------+----------------------------------   Adj R-squared   =    0.7140 #        Total |  1126.04719        31  36.3241028   Root MSE        =    3.2231 #  # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ #          mpg | Coefficient  Std. err.      t    P>|t|     [95% conf. interval] # -------------+---------------------------------------------------------------- #          cyl | #           6  |  -6.920779   1.558348    -4.44   0.000    -10.10796   -3.733599 #           8  |  -11.56364   1.298623    -8.90   0.000    -14.21962   -8.907653 #              | #        _cons |   26.66364   .9718008    27.44   0.000     24.67608    28.65119 # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------  test_that("Standard errors from lm are correct", {   expect_equal(summary(cmod)$coefficients[2, 2], 0.322408,                 tolerance = 0.0001)   expect_equal(summary(fmod)$coefficients[2, 2], 1.558348,                 tolerance = 0.0001)   expect_equal(summary(fmod)$coefficients[3, 2], 1.298623,                 tolerance = 0.0001) })

what: Interact with the GitHub API to get or set issue information — add_label
title: Interact with the GitHub API to get or set issue information — add_label
text: functions provide various ways interact github issues. Open issue: post_issue opens new issue repository, defined body title. Getting issues: get_issue downloads single issue repository. get_issues downloads issues repository. get_test_reports downloads issues repository, filtering test labels, converts issue dataframe. Labels: add_label adds particular label issue. remove_label removes particular label issue. Comments: get_comments downloads comments issue. post_comment posts comment issue. Closing issue: close_issue closes issue. functions primarily use github actions rather standard user.
